title: What does “make America great again' mean? - Quora

response.answer_text: What does “Make America Great Again” mean? I would like to know from those who wear MAGA hats and support this ideology. Wow. OK, I’ll give it a shot. Here is the thing. People hate politicians. Once you understand that, you can start to comprehend why people like Trump. Yes he is corrupt and entitled. However, if you understand that people hate politicians, you will already know that all politicians are corrupt. All politicians get money from special interest groups. All politicians lie while campaigning, and can rarely deliver on those promises. All politicians get in office and realize they can rarely make everyone happy and therefore can rarely make any real difference. All politicians are ‘politically correct’ in publicly saying on those things that are ‘safe’ and ‘polite’ as to not offend anyone. Trump is not a politician. He is rude, and vulgar, and doesn’t really like people. The one thing that Trump is, which makes him similar to anyone who runs for office, he is a patriot. Whether Democrat or Republican, anyone who sacrifices and puts up with D.C., does so because they truly believe they are making a difference. They really believe they can fix the numerous issues with the country. Unemployment. Jobs going overseas. Corruption. Foreign nations stealing our intellectual property. Terrorism. Trade. The bankrupt entitlement system like Social Security. Take your pick. Everyone wants to fix them when it politically expedient and then run as far away when they become bricks that drown your campaign. Trump came in talking like no politician. He didn’t care what people thought of him. He made big promises that other candidates and most of the media thought were crazy. Every president has tried to fix the Mexican border and drug war. Obama, Regan, both Bushs. They all tried and failed to control the influx of immigrants. Trump came out and said he wanted to build a wall and eliminate immigration loopholes. Most people laughed and said it would never happen. Most people also said he would not get elected, not leave Nafta, not pass the tax bill, not pass all of the drug laws, not stand up to China or North Korea, and would never actually stand up to the UN. He did things like pass the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, reauthorized Perkins CTE, added over $6 billion more dollars to fight the opiod trade in the US. He made claims and followed through. Make America Great is about fixing all the crap that is broken. It is about allowing someone into office who will actual do what they say they will without making apologies. That is why Trump will not give in on the border. To him it is a moral issue. He gave his word and like his other promises, he will not back down. People voted for Trump because they figured that election after election after election have gone by with politicians making the same promises and doing nothing. Crime and poverty stays the same, more kids are addicted, and other countries are passing America at an alarming rate. Why not give Trump a try. Ironically, despite his innumerable flaws, he seems to have been the right person at the right time to actually get the job done. Yes, he gave way and lessened restrictions on Russia, but the truth is that they said Clinton would have caused a war because of her stance. However that is the thing with Trump. It is not about making the world a better place or helping everyone else. It is about fixing our own crap first. That is what make America great is. Fix our roads, help our kids, help the unemployed, and fix our economy.

It is the election slogan of Mr. Trump during the 2016 elections. In literal terms, what a great slogan. It means to tell the American people that everything that you have known or seen before Mr. Trump had filed for his nomination, America was in shatters. It was going down. The normal people were becoming poor and losing their jobs and houses. However, little of that is true. Look at the unemployment statistics and the year 2016 was the best year in falling unemployment rate. In perceived terms, it is as fake as any politicians slogan could be. America was great in the 20th century and is still the greatest nation on earth by some margin. Read my answer Vivek Dahiya's answer to Why do you think America is the best country in the world? But, now that the elections are over and Trump has won, it is far easier to comprehend it. The slogan is meant for people who are not progressives and have either lost their jobs or businesses in the last 5 to 10 years. The majority of them belongs to the rust belt states where manufacturing jobs have evaporated due to the natural reasons of low cost of manufacturing to other countries. This is where Trump’s team was instrumental in undertstanding the real under current. The people who were not happy with the democratic administration of Barack Obama. These were the people who because of losing jobs or businesses can vote for any candidate except the democratic candidates. So, let us now talk about how America can become much more greater and keep the politics aside for a minute. When America will stop bombing countries and stop making wars. The wars in the 1990’s and 2000’s were the single most reasons why China was needed to pay the government debt and keep the government functional.When America will stop pretending that it can grow by making the same mistakes of discriminating against the immigrants. The recent elections were in a sort an election of the white supremacy that some Americans were dying to bring back.When America will provide equal rights for women. Even today, being the most powerful country in the world, American women are paid less for the same jobs than their male counterparts do.When America stop this non-sense of reverse brain drain by discouraging more and more high skilled and educated people to look for alternate geographies to live and work for. The situation is so worse that the high skilled people are turning to other countries like Canada and Australia for finding better job opportunities and relaxed visa rules.When America will stop the gun violence by taking away the guns from the hands of normal people. This is something that no nation on this earth could ever understand as to why a normal household needs to have guns. Not good for the safety of right minded people.When America will stop the loot going on in almost all the universities and colleges by bringing down the exorbitant tuition fees so that students can get higher education at much more affordable amounts. Right now, every student is under debt that goes for an undergraduate and post graduate studies. Each one of them. That's why people are now finding it better to study in other countries with comparatively better education facilities and lower education costs.You stay great when you stop pretending that everything is wrong with you and start to act like a mature nation.

I really don`t know. Gathering information from what Trump supporters have said, I deduce that they mean a time when the U.S was strong militarily, the economy was booming thanks to a strong labor force fueled by mining and manufacturing, feminism wasn`t a thing, and people generally fighting for their rights as human beings wasn`t a thing either. A simpler time, when Christian values reigned supreme and people took life on the chin. Probably a time before Jimmy Carter, a self-proclaimed “nice guy”. It was during his presidency that manufacturing peaked, after all. Except, before Jimmy Carter you had a war in Southeast Asia that was majorly unpopular, worsened by the biggest crook possibly ever to inhabit the White House (except for Trump himself, maybe). These Trumpers are also big on honesty in politics- didn`t have that 50 years ago! Going back further, we had MLK, Malcolm X and others constantly fighting for black civil rights, so so much for no one complaining and taking life on the chin. Feminism was also the rage, and was largely incorporated into the black civil rights movement. Double oops. OK, so they must mean the 50s, a quiet, prosperous time for (white) Americans. The men went to work and the wives stayed home, like the Bible intended. Oh, but wait; corporations were taxed at over 90%….by a Republican president?? No, no, that can`t be it. Ooo…this is tough. Given the lack of utopia in recent American history I can only assume they mean a pre-war time, when black people were doing their own thing and whites didn`t have to worry about them and working people were the face of the labor force. Or, even further back, when we were fighting a war over whether or not the southern half of the country was allowed to own slaves and leave the union. Well, that was a pretty discordant time, too…. You get the point. America has always had problems as a nation. With all these ethnicities and races and religions running around, of course they clashed. What these Trump supporters want is to Make America Great Again FOR THEM. The things they complain about and claim to have voted Trump in to fix are the same things they`re disparaging young, working people in other industries for wanting. Or feminists and POC for prostesting. I guess Make America Great Again For Us wouldn`t fit on the cap.

Donald Trump’s campaign slogan “Make American Great Again” is very clever. It said “I will fix what you believe is broken (fill in the blank) about America.” First it appealed to all those voters (70%) that believed the country was going in the wrong direction.It was a clarion call to all of those voters dissatisfied with eight years of Barack Obama as President - half of the country and nearly 100% of Republicans that Trump was trying to win over.It was a dog whistle method of courting all voters that are upset about what has changed in the America - gay marriage, expansion of women’s roles including in the military, inter-racial marriage, growth of cities and decline of rural area economies, immigrants, loss of manufacturing jobs, increasing population of people of color and so on.“Make America Great Again” takes many Americans back to a past utopian time. This works because people forget the bad times and remember the good times of the “good ole days”. For example, when people reflect on growing up in the 1950’s they will remember small towns, kids playing in the street, less crime, a whiter America, women staying at home etc. They will not remember the poverty of older Americans that had no Medicare, the segregation and discrimination Black Americans suffered, the abject and widespread poverty of Appalachia, the fears of the Cold War and nuclear holocaust etc. It is about a “feeling” not a logical and factual evaluation of whether America of 2016 is a better place than America of 1950’s and 60’s. It was a very effectives political slogan at this point in history for an outsider candidate like Donald Trump. To Trump’s creative credit his campaign slogan, “Make America Great Again.” continues to have good utility to mask the actual negative effectives of Trump policies. Even though repeal of the Affordable Care Act would cause 30 million Americans to lose their health insurance, Trump and supporters can trumpet their slogan loudly and repeatedly to create their own reality. Trump is the consummate salesman and has formulated a very effective slogan.

Before we talk about how to make America great again, we have to know what makes America not great anymore.   This video, the beginning scene of the HBO series The Newsroom explains the exactly what the cause is: after the Cold War we think we have no threatening enemies left. We have been so arrogant and we have lost our incentives of competition with the rest of the world.  We are 7th in literacy because our public schools allow our students to drop out a class they feel too hard to learn; We are 49th in life expectancy despite we have the best hospitals because we have a quarter of population that are horribly obese.  These are not the problems, the problem is: we can't blame those stupid teenagers who fail to learn the fundamentals of math, science and literature; we can't even call someone fat even when he or she is 300 pounds and needs to take two seats in a row in the subway.  And they all come from political correctness.  That's what Trump is talking about all the time. We have to be winners, we can't be losers in the world! All races are equal, all genders are equal, people are born with it. Are people born stupid? Are people born fat? Sure some of them are, but only the minorities. Most people fail classes and get obese because of their own problem, not the genes.  Now anyone in our high school who fail to pass a mandatory subject can claim he or she has learning disability, and it has been an excuse for laziness. We have 13% of students receiving special help and it still doesn't make those students performing well in the exams. When international students from eastern Asia feel sad about getting a 2000 on SAT, most American students feel proud when they get a 1600. Obesity doesn't come naturally with high income. Japan has high income but very few Japanese are obese. They know it's important to eat healthy food and exercise to keep themselves slim because if they are obese, they will be laughed at. So many Americans are obese simply because no one stands out in front of them and say "hey you are overweight!", and they will just wrongfully think it's normal and natural to be obese, or even worse they might not realize that they are overweight! Now Trump is the only candidate that stands out, yelling to the crowd:"Hey guys we need to wake up! We are not great anymore! We can't be a country that so many people are losers!" A soldier who got captured was awarded the national hero and became the Republican nominee. Such thing could never happen in Asia.  Why could Japan quickly rebuild itself from ruins and became the second in the world in gross GDP in less than 30 years from WWII? Why could China do the same thing within a generation after the cultural revolution?  Because they like soldiers that weren't captured.  Let's look at mother nature. A tree produces thousands of seeds every year, and only a few of them can grow into another big tree; A fish produces thousands of eggs at the breeding season, and a few of them can survive to adulthood without being eaten by a predator; Hundreds of millions of sperms compete to get the one single egg, all others die.  We are a great species because millions of years ago, only the smarter ones of us survived from climate change in Africa. Those who are smarter gradually differentiate ourselves from apes and evolved into homo sapiens.  We are a great civilization because we won survived during the plagues and wars hundreds of years ago. Those who failed to do so have been buried underground and became history.  We are a great country because we won the independent war, we won the civil war, and we won both world wars. If we lost, America won't be great ever since.  But after that, we lost everything. We have the most powerful army and navy in the world, but we still lost the Korean war, we lost the Vietnam war, and we can't even beat a group of terrorists! Now how can you call our country to be the greatest in the world?! It's competition that makes any individual great, it's competition that makes only the strongest people survive, and those individuals altogether makes the country great. We are great not because we have good facilities for the handicapped, we are great because we have the smartest scientists in our college labs and NASA.  Caring the disadvantaged groups is a very important and essential moral of modern society, but it's not what makes the country great. If we only focus on sympathy and tolerant, and consider competition as hostile and uncivilized behaviors, we will keep losing this country, until the day we really wake up.

Because it is a sound bite for the “Twitter” generation. Really think of any advertisement you see or hear. Usually there is a saying. What Trump did was use his business and advertising skills to tape into a large segment of the US populace. Here are a few examples of memorable tag lines: "Fly the friendly skies" — United Airlines (Leo Burnett)"Where's the beef?" — Wendy's (Cliff Freeman, Dancer Fitzgerald Sample)"We bring good things to life" — GE (Phil Dusenberry, DDBO)"Don't leave home without it" — American Express Card (Bruce Silverman, Ogilvy & Mather)"Be All You Can Be" — U.S. Army (Earl Carter, N.W. Ayer)"Just do it" — Nike (Dan Wieden)"Must-see TV" — NBC (Vince Manze)"Breakfast of champions" — Wheaties (Knox Reeves, Blackett-Sample-Gummert)"Trust the Midas touch" — Midas (Wells, Rich, Greene)It is memorable, appeals to emotions and nostalgia. I recently had a conversation with a friend of mine who is Black. He said that phrase really cannot apply to black Americans. Why? “Well, tell me when America was so “great” how was it great for blacks?” He has a point. No matter what era of history I would bring up, he would discuss the challenges of black America…. I do think this saying though hearkens back to post WWII, when soldiers came home. Jobs were plentiful, manufacturing was high, middle class pay was very good even or those without an education, product prices were cheap, land/homes were affordable, college was affordable, we were expanding technology and manufacturing, etc… highways were being built out so Americans were getting the freedom of mobility. By the time our discussion closed, we decided “Make America Great for ALL”. Would be better.

It’s just a slogan with great emotional appeal apparently but no real substance. There are several people who think the world they knew is slipping away from them. Partially it’s economics — flat income — but that’s not the most important feature. It’s the sense that the Other is taking over — all those Muslims, Hispanics, homosexuals, and African Americans getting privileges they haven’t earned and who are often violent to boot.. The moral rules they grew up with seem no longer to be sacred, Christianity is threatened, there are too many people who don’t share our values who seem to be in control. If you think about it “Making America Great Again” ought to appeal mostly to young people since they have the most to benefit from alleged improvements. Instead it’s the older folks who bought into the rhetoric, people who wish we could return to the 50s and early 60s when life was a lot more simple and there wasn’t all this questioning of morals and standards. The Other stayed in his place. These feelings have been fairly significant for some time, and had a big role to play in the attempts to portray Obama as the ultimate Other — not born in the US probably a Muslim, etc. It is no accident that one of the best predictors of Trump support after age and education is negative racial attitudes. This is not racism in the conventional sense. It is not hatred; rather it’s more like wariness or a strong sense of discomfort, even fear. So the dog whistle appeals sell among those who genuinely don’t feel that they hate blacks. Most of them don’t, but hidden in that appeal is the notion hat minorities are eroding conventional moral standards and self-reliance. So like Nixon’s war on crime and Reagan’s war on drugs, both of which were dog whistle slogans targeting race, lyou get to have your cake and eat it too. I don’t hate minorities, but they really don’t follow the rules so I can express negative views without focusing on race as such. It just happens that the people who are out of touch with conventional morality happen to be minorities, or at least that’s the logic. Of course by any identifiable standards America is in pretty good shape. But that “success” if you want to call it that is not evenly spread. Trump’s slogan was actually very clever. He didn’t need to deal with facts; instead he just made up a bunch of stuff that “proved” we were decline. The appeal was purely emotional which is why it’s been so frustrating that the Trumpies seem oblivious to the fact that he is selling them out and that most of his claims were easily shown to be fraudulent. But in this case his words speak much louder than his actions — often the case with emotional appeals. Democrats are now focusing on what they can do to lower income inequality and create better jobs. But that isn’t the real problem. The basic issues are much deeper and are harder to confront.

Like all good slogans, this one can mean pretty much whatever you want it to mean.  One of Trump's strengths is that he has no real political record, and he's said all sorts of things over the years, and has made it clear that he often doesn't really mean what he says. That means that people who are  inclined to like him can project their own views onto him, broadening his appeal. However, I think that to the core Republican voters this has a pretty specific meaning.  This group deeply believes that President Obama has not only  been bad for America, but he has been purposefully bad for America, weakening the military, filling the country with illegal immigrants and Muslim refugees, giving favorable treatment to African Americans, apologizing all over the world, encouraging Muslim terrorists, oppressing Christians, and generally dissing and hurting  white people, especially white men.  This is seen as an extension of Democratic policies and social change dating back variously to the 1960's, the Civil Rights movement, or FDR's New Deal. To those people "make America great" means to undo those things, beginning with undoing President Obama's changes. A brilliant thing about this slogan is that it hits the very powerful nostalgia button, which is an especially good move for  older voters, who vote more than younger ones and are especially well-represented in the Republican Party.  People often look at the past as a time when the world (and the country) was much better, where there was optimism and opportunity and people were better. Funnily enough, if you ever question people about when they thought the world was great, it usually is when they were in the early 20's.  Trump's slogan allows people to imagine he will return the US to the way it was in their youth, forgetting that the thing that made it so great at the time was being young.

I believe in the context the president meant it on the campaign trail and what I ascertain by his actions as peesident is a return to the rule of law and to the principles of the Constitution. The Constitution is a pretty straightforward document….and only occasionally open to interpretation. The last president felt that it was an archaic document that had outlived its usefulness. As a result he would bypass it by circumventing congress entirely and govern by executive actions. He even famously said he knew that DACA was illegal but that sis not stop him from doing it. What makes Trump different is a return to the principles that made us the premiere global superpower. Things like doing the right thing rather than the popular thing. Yes, staying in the Iran deal would have made our european allies happy, but do we really want to pump any more money into Irans economy when they use it to fund terror and test ballistic missiles with it? Obama was clearly not concerned by this but Trump is. Also becoming great again means making trade deals that are fair and equitable rather than some of the one sided deals we have had in the past. Another thing that make this country great is the strongest military on the planet. Trump has made great strides to return our combat readiness to what it used to be. We used to revere our veterans….we need to do that again. Same goes for first responders. Being great again means respecting free speech rights and not shutting down ideas that we find offensive like they do on college campuses like Cal Berkely. Being great means respecting religious freedom. No one should have to violate their religious beliefs or be put out of business by the state. Being great means taking advantage of our vast natural resources and not hampering our businesses with needless and foolish regulations. It also means making every citizen responsible for the kind of country we have. Punish criminals. Reward good behavior. Strive for excellence. Everyone should not always get a trophy! We need to return to the country we were when we stood up to evil, when we had steel in our spines, where we could go through any hardship, when we would rather die than give up our freedoms. That was a country to be proud of. That was when we were truly great!

In Trump's interpretation, it means “let's get back to life in the 1950’s”. He wants corporate America to basically bully the country into being allowed to do anything they want. He wants workers to report to their factory jobs everyday, carrying their lunch boxes, packed by their stay at home housewives. He wants the children of these workers to realize they are the next generation of factory workers (or forced to serve in the military), while they watch the children of rich people head off to college. He wants blacks to be put back in their place, at the back of the bus, and in their own subpar neighborhoods. He wants women to be at home, cleaning and cooking for their husbands. He wants bosses to be able to pinch their secretaries bottoms, without fear of negative reprecussions. And of course, there were no immigrants or gays in the '50's, so they need to go away today. A few migrant workers to serve as fruit pickers, gardeners for the wealthy, or to work in Trump hotels, will be fine, but the rest need to go back to wherever they came from. Gays should be forced back in the closet, so they can’t indoctrine more people into their loathsome lifestyle. Oh and let's not forget, women should not have the right to make decisions regarding their bodies. That right belongs to their husband only. Abortions should be illegal, unless you are wealthy and can afford a private physician to perform the dirty deed in private. That's how Trump would make America great again. Great for him, and people that share his wealth or mindset. I personally prefer an America that progresses forward, not moves backward.

“Make America Great Again” is an empty slogan that is specifically designed for people who are disaffected in various ways to project onto it. Many people who voted for Trump did so because they are disaffected in some way or frustrated with the system. The reasons for them being disaffected may come in various guises, and a lot of them are just… the struggles are real, but their idealized solutions are not realistic or are the equal to shooting the US in the foot. For instance, when Trump pulled the US out of the Paris Accords, my mother was trawling around on Facebook, and reading the comments about it. (I never read the comments, but she does.) There were a lot of people in the comments being like, “Good, now maybe the coal miners’ suffering will be alleviated.” Jesus Christ. The coal miners. It’s not that the suffering of many people in mining and manufacturing isn’t real. (I am from Detroit. Trust me, I am familiar with what happens to people who manufacturing gets outsourced or whatnot.) I also am related to coal miners. However, guys… the future is not in coal. Yes, it sucks to be a coal miner and be out of work. I am also sure it sucked to be a blacksmith or a wheelwright at the time when those industries went to hell. But the future was not in blacksmithing or wheelwrighting. The solution is not to pull out of trans-national accords in order to protect coal miners. The solution is to help people transition out of coal mining into more viable industries. Get people the education and skills they need to thrive in future-looking industries. Like, for instance, I make my living mostly on the internet in a variety of verticals. I write all different kinds of advertising copy and ebooks and whatever the hell people pay me to write. I teach English both in-person and virtually. I know how to run dropshipping businesses through ebay. I build websites. I do graphic design. Whatever. I make my living through these skills. I am a skilled worker. The trouble with coal mining (and manufacturing) is that many of those jobs are unskilled. The need for unskilled labor is declining sharply. This is not going to be changed by the US pulling out of the Paris Accords. But people think it will. They are looking for a band-aid solution to the problem. They are looking to “go back” to when America was “great” and coal mining was indeed a very stable and good job that could provide a living for a family on a single income. They want that back. Those days are gone, guys. They are gone. They are not coming back. It’s a bunch of fuckery, is what it is.

I think it means, the United States needs to be again, dominant in every corners in the world. This is how “Make American Great Again” looks like. Well, Mr. Trump copied the slogan from Mr. Reagan and he pointed very clever moment at the time when the U.S.A. is currently, not in good moment to do so. Think about it! Economic trouble! Immigrant trouble! And then, the political fading through. How about it? Trump jumped right on the time the U.S. is in serious trouble. No matter what, he was smart that time. He might know he could not win by popular, but when he pointed on the angers of Americans right then, he had totally stroke down Hillary Clinton. It has a very strong effect on the people. It burned the feeling of Americans, making Americans feeling that the U.S. is in a trouble time and only Trump could save the U.S.. He did. He achieved what was the goal to be. That’s how it worked. And now we need to see how the U.S. goes after 2 years in Presidency of Mr. Trump.

This is just my opinion. They say opinions are “a dime a dozen—therefore my opinion is worth less than two cents. I do not have the details in front of me, but I heard the story of a European man sent by his leader to find out why America was great. The man reportedly came to America and began his quest for his leader. He searched in America’s schools, and universities. He searched in industry, medicine, science, etc., and could not find the reason for America’s greatness. Then he search in America’s churches; it was in the churches he reportedly found his answer. America was great because America was basically good. And if America ever ceased being good, it would be all over. The U. S. has a history of good points and bad points. We have landed on the moon, had advancements in medicine, science, and, engineering, provided literature, and offered a safe haven to people seeking relief from oppression. America also offerd rights to citizens other countries only offer as privlidges . We have also enslaved people, experimented on human beings without their knowledge, murdered, stolen property under the guise of taxes, ruined people’s lives and starved German POW’s at the end of WW2. These are both good and bad points, but people supposedly generally knew there were lines not to be crossed. Now a person can say what they want, but in 1963, the United States removed organized prayer and Biblical teaching from public schools. Statistics are there that indicate America began a downward spiral at this point. The statistics include exponential increase in crime, illicit drug use, single mother pregnancies, increase in sexually transmitted diseases, previously unacceptable behavior slowly accepted. In addition, we lost the Vietnam War, experienced the Watergate conspiracy, had hostages taken in Iran, and began to be hated in many parts of the world. Again, that is my opinion, but I’ve seen the statistics and they appear to correlate with this event in 1963. There are those of us that wish to bring the pre-1963 morals back. To those against us, I would say that the proposed “wall” along the southern border is not meant to keep people in. Hint, hint.

To me Make America Great Again means that the current political powers, in particular the American Republican party but not just them, are getting desperate. Their plans and beliefs have fallen apart to such a degree that the only thing many of them can think to do is to start going backwards to what used to work. Many of our leaders are in their twilight with the average age in the legislature having been pushed up to the mid-fifties and early-sixties which leaves many of them struggling to adapt. They did not grow up in the world we live in today where so much has changed in a very short time after all. For the Republicans who coined the phrase after being forced to work with Donald Trump they mean going back to a time when American exceptionalism was the norm, manufacturing jobs were plentiful, and they were free to look down on minority groups without backlash. They are doomed in the endeavor to roll back the clock though. Both because the majority simply doesn’t agree with what they want to do, socially they have a very small but extremely loyal following, and because the conditions that created the time they remember are no longer present. The golden age they hearken back do was not around because people were more bigoted meaning they put pressure on everyone else to be “normal” or because people “pulled themselves up by their bootstraps” but because most of the world had just had its industrial capacity blown to hell leaving the United States with a monopoly on many products along with automation having not been anywhere near as wide spread. For the Democrats the phrase Make America Great Again is an ultimatum. It’s a statement of the intention to take away everything they worked for decades to accomplish and to forceably turn back the clock on all the progress made while utterly failing to adapt to the situations of today.

A picture is worth a thousand words. The impression I get is similar to what I get with Main Street U.S.A. As in the first area of any Walt Disney theme park.  No historical main street has ever looked like this however, as every version in the Disney theme parks is an anachronistic cross-country mishmash. The typical area of Main Street USA will have architecture from between 1850 and 1930. There will be buildings characteristic of historic Rhode Island right next door to something straight from New Orleans’ French Quarter. It’s so broadly representative of a historic America it fails to represent anywhere specific. But it’s just narrowly representative enough that those who don’t fully know the story think it does. Unconsciously picking the when and where based on their own perceptions. This is MAGA. Just like how Disney’s Main Street USA presents a fantastical American yesteryear as a historical time gone by, so too is MAGA designed to evoke memories of an idealised America. It particularly capitalises on memories of the Cold War, that time remembered as when America was a lone bastion of free expression and free enterprise in the world. As many of the phrase's targets look back on the Second World War and the following post-war boom with nostalgia as America’s greatest golden age. At its core, MAGA is a Rorschach test and a cold reading in one easily-pronounceable package. It condenses down into four words “whatever ideal image you’re thinking America used to be, I will give it to you.” Like the current calls for unity however, it also plays people against each other without being innately antagonistic. On the surface it sounds neutral, and opposing it would be insane on paper. After all why would any American not want their country to be amazing? But the intent in this instance is not neutral, the vision being suggested through policy and hostility to minority groups has losers, people will suffer under this new version of America. So you get people who want America great, but not in the way sold to voters through promise and policy. When the intent of the phrase is called into question, the outward neutrality of the phrase itself opens up any critics for ridicule. It doesn’t matter if the in-crowd can’t agree what this great vision looks like, the out-group end up identifying themselves as disagreeing with what the in-group want. Reinforcing ideas the out-group wish nothing but harm to the nation. If you see through or reject MAGA, you become a target by those who bought it because to them your opposition is saying you don't want a great America.

Greatness is a relative term, isn’t it? We could, for example, say that Rome in the days of Augustus Caesar was a great place… as was (for example) London in the days when Queen Victoria reigned. But the average citizen living in those times did not live spectacularly well; only the very wealthy did. The ancient Roman, or the resident of London in its days of “greatness,” could take some pleasure in knowing he or she lived in the supposedly greatest Empire of its era. Yet this was a small consolation at a time when life was still hard for most people, and unless you were in the ruling class, you worked very, very hard for only a small portion of the nation’s largesse. Now, let’s consider America: or rather the USA. Would you say that America post-WW2 was as “great” as living in ancient Rome or Victorian England? I would say greater! The USA after WW2 emerged as the leading economy in the entire world… the greatest producer, the greatest exporter, the greatest economic engine, the greatest educational system, and (for what it’s worth) the greatest military power the world had ever seen. By far. But the real greatness of the USA lay in the fact that with its expanding middle class, the fantastic largesse that came to the country was spread to people far, far outside the top 1%… that even children of working class could aspire to the highest offices in the land… far more than had ever been possible in “Republican” Rome (which was really a plutocracy dominated by the weathliest families) or in London’s Parliament — which likewise was dominated by the House of Lords, along with wealthy merchants who controlled the House of Commons. America’s greatness continued even into turbulent times, when — despite the original sin of slavery and racism — the youth of America rose up to demand civil rights and an end to an unpopular war. For all its problems, America in the 1950s, 1960s, 1970s, and beyond, was in many ways the greatest country that ever was… NOT because it was perfect and unchanging, but precisely because it was so willing to address the problems of a free society: In those days, so many were able to rise from poverty, and so many young people were willing and able to speak truth to power. If I had to choose, I would say a Hillary or Bernie presidency would have had the best chance of preserving this greatness that was America.

Like many slogans, “Make America Great Again’ comes across as simplistic. It supposes that America was once great but is no longer. In all cultures, conservatives use an idealized past as a benchmark for the present and a dreamed-of future. Ergo, the America of their memory was great and the America they experience now isn’t. Encapsulated within the ‘Make America Great Again’ slogan are a series of idealistic visions tailor-made for conservatives. For Trump’s core audience, working class people whose jobs have disappeared, the slogan means “Let’s fix stuff that we don’t like about the country. Let’s create more ‘good’ jobs, stop corporations from exporting jobs overseas, build a more powerful military, get better trade deals, make NATO countries pay their agreed-upon share, protect our borders to save and cut down on drug flow and crime, reduce taxes and fix our bridges, roads and dams.” It’s easy to be skeptical about such goals being accomplished in four, let alone eight or 16 years. The slogan ’Make America great again’ acts as a shorthand that says that all such improvements are possible. The ‘Make America great again’ slogan would never work with liberals: They believe the past and present are filled with injustice and inequity and the best is still out there to be achieved. Their slogan might read ‘Make America great,’ but I’m not sure that would work either. Most liberals of my acquaintance would see ‘Make America great’ as chauvinistic and a violation of their dream of a world without borders.

Observed from any other time in history, the USA and the rest of Western society is presently stunningly, stunningly better than anything else that has gone before. And it is getting better all the time. There will always be room for improvement, and there will always be disagreements on how exactly to move forward, but our society is working extraordinarily well. But what has happened is that the science of insult and complaint has, for the time being, become much more powerful and successful than the science of defence against insult and complaint. It is very easy to say thing that resonate with sections of the electorate, “Make America great again”, “It's the fault of illegal immigrants”, “That particular politician has broken the law and should be in jail” and hundreds of other such insults and complaints. Countering these insults and complaints requires discussion and debate and in present times, few people are prepared to enter into such time consuming activity. When exactly was the time when America was greater than the present? Was it in the days of polio, smallpox and cholera? Was it the days of McCarthy or Nixon? Perhaps is was the days when members of the community could be excluded from schools and universities, or casually lynched, because of the colour of their skin. Or was it the days of the Great Depression? And if we exclude immigrants, or tax food imports from Mexico, won't food prices go up? All these points require discussion and debate, but such discussion and debate is nowhere near as powerful as the initial insult or complaint. One final point - let's not get into a discussion or debate on what is actually wrong with present society. The point I'm making is that the science of insult and complaint is more powerful than the science of defence against insult and complaint.

What would you say is the most important word in the MAGA slogan? Here’s a clue - compare it to the campaign slogan for the Brexit ‘leave’ campaign: Take Back Control (UK ‘leave’ campaign) Make America Great Again (US Trump campaign) Both phrases exhibit key copywriting (marketing) techniques: Directly address the audience, using the 2nd person imperative.Encourage/empower the audience to take a particular action.Hillary Clinton’s slogan (Stronger Together) doesn’t do these things; the ‘remain’ campaign in the UK was so anaemic, it didn’t even have a slogan. But the most important word in the MAGA slogan is ‘again’, just like the most important word in the Brexit ‘leave’ slogan is ‘back’. It does three things. It creates a linear time narrative - a before, a now and a future: A story.It addresses the audience as the central protagonist in the ‘now’ part of that story.In the story, the protagonist lost something precious. Now, the protagonist has a chance to get that thing back.It’s the essential quest narrative: Literally, the oldest trick in the book. When Jason goes in pursuit of the Golden Fleece, we know it’s going to be an action-packed adventure - but that’s not enough to win our sympathy. To make our hearts burn for Jason, the story needs pathos.  That’s why, before Jason sets off on his quest, he is wrongfully deprived of his father’s throne - his birthright - by his nasty usurper uncle. Now, Jason has suffered an injustice. This changes the narrative completely - he has a moral cause AND a material cause motivating his quest. The good is on his side and the good will out. It’s the same plot for Shakespeare’s Hamlet and Disney’s Lion King: Evil uncle steals father’s throne, hero is exiled, hero reclaims birthright/has his revenge. It’s the same basic model for Star Wars, Harry Potter, Gladiator, and any action movie that starts with a musclebound hero losing his family and being wrongly imprisoned or exiled. It’s also the reason so many people find Lord of the Rings such an impressive work of fantasy yet somehow, on some basic level, kind of …weak: It’s because Tolkien makes a point of not equipping Frodo with a burning sense of personal injustice. It was apparently important for Tolkien to have a hero motivated by nothing more than simple goodness of heart. Which is laudable …just not great pathos. In fact, Frodo’s “Fellowship of the Ring” is an awful lot like Hillary’s “Stronger Together” in this way: Laudable, but no match for burning injustice. Reading too much into it? Speechwriters and copywriters do think long and hard about how to distil the most potent messages for their audiences. There are reasons why some slogans work better than others and why writers can be paid so much for crafting a single line.

These investment banks that control the media(both entertainment and news), politics, and the rest of the banking system with their money power. To me, “Make America Great Again” most strongly means going back to easier times in terms of making/keeping our own money, having our equal freedoms (especially in regards to freedom of speech, expression, religion), and being equal under the law. A lot of what Trump spoke against in 2016 was the political correctness that the far left was pushing - mainly the ideas that their beliefs had to be known and all opposition had to be silenced. I’m being hyperbolic, of course, but we are seeing much of that today. And with the political correctness, those who disagree with the alt-left are often silenced, physically attacked, or shamed. People of faith are shunned for striving to obey their religious convictions. “Make America Great Again” represents going back to a time where people could respectfully agree to disagree, instead of disowning friends, family members, etc for having different views than them.

It’s tempting to think it means that Trump acting as though the America he fell into ruling had already fallen to demons, is a good way to disguise the fact that each bodily movement of his swings a sloppy gargantuan tail that smashes everything in its wake. But that would have required too much self-awareness and forethought. “Make America Great Again” is simply Tantrump’s invitation to his avid troop of marauding goons to take a shit on the country and feel heroic about it.

I would assert that President Trump is a narcissist and that his world view is based upon that. I’m reading between the lines, but I believe the idea behind “Make America Great Again” is that we are no longer a country which is first among equals. Instead of being fearful of retribution, North Korea continues a policy of arming itself and defying a “let’s all try to get along” attitude. Iran continues to refer to us as the Great Satan. Russia annexes a section of the Ukraine and funds a group who likely shot down a civilian passenger plane In a “Make America Great Again” world, everyone would want to negotiate with us and would give us more favorable terms because they are negotiating from weakness. If a country took an action we didn’t like, we would simply intimidate them into backing down. Personally I tend to a view in which cooperation and consensus are more effective than unilateral action. But the world is complex and sometimes requires exceptional actions. We can debate the merits of such a world but I don’t know that we would accomplish more than offering our opinions and being unable to sway the other.

If that were the case they would support funding through reasonable taxation our educational systems, our research centers, our care for the underprivileged of this country, NASA, the EPA - all the things that would strengthen our country. It is an branding slogan. It means as much as the person purchasing the product THEY imagine it to be —and that is to stand out and capture the attention better than the competing product so you’ll buy it. Harley Davidson’s slogan was “American by Birth. Rebel by Choice.” A fine slogan. What does that mean to you? Is it any different than “Make America Great Again?” Think before you answer and ponder these: Some will say: “Well I don’t want a motorcycle, so it means nothing to me!” (These are buyers who aren’t swayed by slogans. Doesn’t mean they won’t buy YOUR product, just means other factors influence their decisions.)Others will say, “I’m not buying a motorcycle but if I did, this will make me consider a Harley!” (These are buyers you can get to buy into your slogan and influence others to as well.)People who ALREADY have a Harley will feel…PRIDE, pride in their Bikes — and that means a pride in America and those people will tell others to buy American, buy a Harley. (These are buyers who are brand loyal)And still others will say, “Are they kidding?!?! Who are they trying to fool — their bikes parts are made in Mexico and Europe and are just assembled in America! That’s why I only ride Indian Motorcycles!” (These are informed buyers.)One of favorite branding slogans? “Like It Never Happened.” Service Pro, the folks who are called to clean up major accident industrial accidents like fires, tornadoes, chemical spills (they now do smaller ones). Perfect slogan. Now, imagine that on a campaign 2020 button….

A similar negative perception exists for a segment of the electorate. Others feel everything is just fine. MAGA is a hope of the disaffected that political and economic measures can regain a feeling of optimism and security. Whether this is possible remains to be seen. In essence it is an example of seeing a glass as half full or half empty. Some feel Trump’s proposed measures are destructive, others feel they are constructive.

I’m under no illusion that there was some golden age in the US when there were no problems. I’m also not so pessimistic as to think things are impossibly terrible now, in spite of concerns that could probably be addressed. With those two things being said, I think the things that have made the US great are the following: We have always respected the rule of law and we have always tried to have reliable laws. This has allowed people to be able to count on certain things happening or not happening.We have always tried to have functional institutions. Sometimes we have swung more in favor of government institutions, and sometimes we have favored less, but we always have had some. This has allowed people to be able to expect to get things done when they go down to an office or apply for something. They may not be as efficient as people would hope, but they have rarely degenerated into a situation of corruption and cronyism where the only hope of getting anything is by knowing someone or paying someone off.We have a decentralized system of education that has allowed for a lot of dynamic adaptation to needs without falling prey to an overwhelming slate of top-down mandates. Over the years we have greatly increased access to education, to the point that almost everyone has a decent chance to be able to learn to read and write and much more.We have had a vibrant free-market economic system that has allowed people to pursue their creative interests and that has added some incentive to do better or improve ones life. Sometimes we allow some gaming of the system to create monopolies or leave people behind, and other times we have clamped down, perhaps to the point of stifling some economic opportunities, but overall, we have managed to have decent balance.The last two points depend on the first two points to work. Together, all of these things have allowed the US to be innovative, progressive, successful, and prosperous, and we have been able to not only attract others who seek this to come here, but also to serve as a model for other countries who would like to live the same way. To me this is what American greatness is all about. We still have very strong aspects of all of these things and so I think we are a great country. However, there is always room for improvements or for getting back to the basics in some of these areas. So for me, any attempt to “make America great again” or perhaps better said, to “focus on what makes America great”, we should never lose sight of what it is that actually makes us great and to always be on the lookout to protect those things and allow them to continue as time may require adaptations in the way we apply them.

It meant that this was the first slogan on the road to fascism. Trump is not a populist; he is not the alone single one who can fix it; he is a power hungry and whiny little bitch. He is the Swamp Creature from the Black Lagoon. He is a hateful, spiteful, uneducated man-child whose suits don’t fit. He has taken the exact ass-backwards wrong positions on almost everything, from the TPP, the Paris Climate Accords, and the JCPOA. He doesn’t read. He doesn’t listen. All you Trumpers who expect that the summit with Kim Jung Il will go well are looking at the this through Trump-colored glasses. And further, that the Mueller investigation is going to end up devastating for The Moron. I’ll give better than even odds that this aberrant administration is going to end up badly. This guy is going to FUBAR America. Not make it great again.

You’d have to ask him. As others have said, he may not even have anything specific in mind when he says that. After all, his idea of “Make America great again” may not be the same as your idea, but by not defining it, he was letting you assume that he meant the same thing you thought of as making America great again. I think if you tried to nail him down on it, he’d probably go with the economic titan that was the USA in either the 50’s/60’s, or the 80’s. The 80’s would be debateable, as the “greed is good” culture doesn’t have as much respect now as it did then. Now, let’s further assume that he’s referring strictly to the economy and not the social situation. I can’t rule out that he’s thinking of a time when men were the providers and women were in the kitchen as being a good thing, but I’m not going to assume that he is. Even with that assumption, regaining that position isn’t as feasible as some would like to think. Others have said that the jobs that have gone overseas won’t come back very easily, but I’ll go even farther than that. Even if you get those jobs back, we won’t be the same powerhouse. You see, the 50’s and 60’s rode on the industrial buildup of WWII. During WWII, the US did an amazing job of focusing on industry, waking the sleeping giant that some say Admiral Isoroku Yamamoto referred to. Do you really think we can achieve that level of focus without something like another world war? On top of that, the reason we were an industrial giant at that time was because we took no damage to our infrastructure during the war. At the end of the war, US industry (at least partially) turned from the “war machine” to non-war markets. The industry of other countries, on the other hand, turned to rebuilding their country, giving the US a head start. Furthermore, even what economy we have now isn’t the same focus as it was then. Back then, we were an industrial nation first and foremost. We had no trade deficit. The trade deficit really wasn’t a thing until the 70’s, peaking under Bush(43), and bouncing back a little over a year into Obama’s administration. However, this isn’t necessarily a bad thing. You see, the trade deficit only considers hard goods. Services and such don’t get counted as part of it, and as soon as you do, the US is back to positive numbers (or was last time I researched it). If you want an example of non-hard goods, think movies. I’m talking actual theater movies that typically take in much more world wide than they do in the US. The US has been turning away from manufacturing hard goods since the trade deficit was a thing. Ever since I was in high school, (late 70’s to early 80’s), I’ve been saying that trying to keep the manufacturing jobs here is the wrong thing for government to try to do, we need to do better at transitioning people out of manufacturing jobs and supporting them through that transition. I didn’t know when robotics would take over so much of manufacturing, but I knew the time was coming. Assembly line work has been more robot than human for a while, but it won’t stop there. I don’t know if they followed through on it, but McDonald's was going to open it’s first fully automated restaurant over a year ago. AI is slowly threatening jobs that aren’t even manufacturing or food service. Seriously, trying to relive the good old days in modern times is going to result in the modern times curb stomping us. If we pressure businesses to not automate, then they’ll get undercut by those that do. And no, I don’t have the answer on how to best adapt to the changing work environment. If anyone has an even semirealistic idea, I’m all ears. And yes, I’d love to be proven wrong on this and have and economy where people aren’t worried about losing their jobs to outsourcing or automation or just plain cheaper entry level labor. I’m not an economist, so I could be wrong. The thing is, neither is Donald Trump. He’s a business man, and granted a better one than I would be. He’s shown that even if it doesn’t come naturally to him, he can take advice, and this is something he needs to take advice on. Sorry, I honestly didn’t mean to carry on this long. TLDR: We had advantages in the good old days that we don’t have now, and even if we could overcome the lack thereof, going back to the good old days would handicap us.
